4.heading: Watching.
4.title: "Charlie Brown in Indian Country"

notes: Summary: Charlie Brown is buried to his neck in the desert, and a vulture is watching him.

5.heading: Watching.
5.title: "Go Ahead, Watch!"
5.author: Bob Montana.
notes: Summary: Pop says no credit, then asks for collateral; Archie says he'll give him a watch.

6.heading: Watching.
6.title: "I Minds Me Own Business"

6.series: For Better or For Worse, Oct. 30, 1998
notes: Summary: Mike and Weed return to their apartment and see Mrs. Dingle watching them, though she denies it.

7.heading: Watching.
7.title: "I'd Like Half that Pizza with Cheese and the Other Half with Dog Food"
7.author: Ketcham.
notes: Summary: Ruff is watching as Dennis phones in an order.

8.heading: Watching.

notes: ca. 250 p. : ill. ; 18 cm.

9.heading: Watching.
9.title: "No Word from Tommy and Skeeter"
9.author: by Glenn Chaffin and Hal Forrest.
notes: Summary: A crowd is watching for Tommy and Skeeter's three-point high-wing mono with one motor; a tri-motor comes into sight but that's not their Cherry Blossom.

10.heading: Watching.
10.title: "Now Watch the Movie or I'll Spray You with Adapted Mace and Watch You Scream"
10.author: by Peter O'Donnell.
notes: Summary: Blenkinsop is watching them on his computer screen.
Printed in the Detroit Free Press, Mar. 8, 2000.

11.heading: Watching.
11.title: "Oh, Boy! It's Dog Food Again!"
11.author: Larson.
notes: Summary: Two dogs are watching their mistress empty a can into their dog dish.

12.heading: Watching.

13.heading: Watching.
13.title: "She Seemed to Catch Her Second Wind after the Rottweiler Started Chasing Her!"
13.author: Batiuk & Ayers.
notes: Summary: Crankshaft has been watching one of the students' mothers chase the bus.

14.heading: Watching.
14.title: "There Goes the Star"
14.author: Patrick McDonnell.
notes: Summary: Earl says the world's a stage from his window, as he watches his owner walk past.

15.heading: Watching.
15.title: "There's a Lot to Learn from Watchin' Somebody Mow a Lawn!"
15.author: Marlette.
notes: Summary: Kudzu asks Uncle Dub to babysit Doris while he mows the lawn; Doris ends up riding on the mower handle.

16.heading: Watching.
16.title: "You've Got To Watch Some of His Golfing Friends"
16.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: A golfer reports his score a little too optimistically.

17.heading: Watching Airplanes.
17.title: "The Boys Welcome the DO-X!"

notes: Summary: Before setting out on their trip the racers watch the Dornier Flying Boat land near the Golden Gate.

18.author: [No author]

19.title: Watching Anime, Reading Manga : 25 Years of Essays and Reviews

21.heading: Watching Balls.
21.title: "I Look On Him as the Indoor Equivalent to a Sand Trap"

notes: Summary: Kit is doing some putting practice, and Carlyle watches the ball attentively.

22.heading: Watching Barbers.
22.title: "Looks Like a Big Day for Everybody"

notes: Summary: Amos is on his way to Low Fidelity Records to sign a contract selling the Hoople Dictation Discs; Twiggs has only been watching an apprentice barber shave a wrestler, so he'll come along.

24.heading: Watching Cats.
24.title: "Cat Courting"
24.author: Batiuk & Ayers.
notes: Summary: From his lawn chair, Crankshaft watches his tomcat make friends with a female cat. Silent strip.

25.heading: Watching Cats.
25.title: "Honeybunch, She's a Cat!"
25.author: by Kevin Fagan.
notes: Summary: We can't go to Las Vegas, who'll watch Oogie?

26.heading: Watching Clowns.

27.title: "Autumn is Here and the Dogs are Falling"

28.heading: Watching Dogs.
28.title: "He Never Has a Problem with Priorities"

29.heading: Watching Dogs.
29.title: "He's Waiting For Us to Stop Watching"

30.heading: Watching Dogs.
30.title: "Look What That Bad Dog Did To My Doll"

31.heading: Watching Dogs.
31.title: "Makes You Want to Throw Up, Doesn't It?"
31.author: Piraro.
notes: Summary: Two cats are watching a dog deliver the newspaper to its owner.

32.heading: Watching Eyes.

33.heading: Watching Games.

35.heading: Watching Golf.

36.heading: Watching Hungrily.
36.title: "Make the Call, and No Tricks"
36.author: by Bob Lubbers.

After cleaning up at poker the Professor is headed for Las Vegas, where he's working on the odds of filling an inside straight, but they think Jake Hoople is a match for him. Call no.: PN6726f.B55 "odds"

65.heading: Watching Television.

65.author: A

72.heading: Watching Television.

76.heading: Watching Television.

77.author: Bell-Lundy.

116.heading: Watchmen--Miscellanea.
116.title: The History of the Comics [videorecording]
116.author: EPISA (Euskal Pictures International, S
116.appears_in: A.) ; co-production, ETB (Euskal Telebista) ; The Department of Culture of the Basque government ; with support from the Spanish Ministry of Culture ; producer, Iñigo Silva ; director, Alejandro Vallejo ; script, Carmen Dominguez, Alejandro Vallejo.
notes: 4 VHS videocassettes (ca. 360 min.) : sd., col. and b&w ; 1/2 in.

Summary: Four-part series on the history of comics. Volume 1 follows the beginnings of comics and some of the comic book characters that were popular during the turn of the century, World War I, the Roaring '20s and the Great Depression. Volume 2 deals with the superheroes and characters with superhuman powers that are still popular today, just as they were 40 and 50 years ago. It also discusses how the 1950s and 1960s inspired the creation of a whole new cast of comic characters for a baby boom generation. Volume 3 looks at the underground movement of the 1960s and the alternative-style comics it produced that ferociously attacked society. It also discusses the superheroes of the 1970s and 1980s and the impact of the Punk movement on comics. Volume 4 wraps up the series with the new changes in comics, from superheroes who are becoming more human to dealing with ecological disasters and drugs. The program also looks at the future of comics and features today's young artists and writers.
Contents v 1: The Katzenjammer kids ; Betty Boop ; Little Orphan Annie ; Popeye ; Tarzan ; Gasoline Alley ; Dick Tracy ; Flash Gordon ; The Phantom.
v. 2: Superman ; Batman ; Steve Canyon ; Peanuts ; Captain America ; James Bond ; Beetle Bailey ; Mad ; Andy Capp.
v. 3: Vampirella ; Conan ; Furry Freak Brothers ; Spider-Man ; Little Annie Fanny ; Incredible Hulk ; Fantastic Four ; Creepy magazine ; Judge Dredd.
v. 4: X-Men ; Outland ; Heavy Metal ; Green Arrow ; Watchmen ; Atom ; Elf Quest ; Ronin ; Green Lantern.

129.heading: Watchmen--Miscellanea.
129.title: "Pétillon Wins Grand Prix"
129.author: Jacques Dutrey & Jean-Paul Jennequin
129.appears_in: p. 24-25 in the Comics Journal, no. 129 (May 1989)
notes: Lists the awards at the Angouléme festival. The Alfreds are now called "Alph'arts." Best album is Marie Verité (Yann and Le Gall); best foreign album is Les Gardiens (=Watchmen) (Moore & Gibbons); best humor album is Les Vieux Copains Pleins de Pepins (Cestac); Best first album: Le Journal de Henriette (Berberian & Dupuy); best album for young people: Aquablue (Cailleteau), Prix Lucien: Le Grand Pouvoir du Chninkel (Van Hamme & Rosinski), and other awards. Grand prize winners for 1974 through 1988 are also listed.
